title: 110_hr836
content: The "Cyber-Security Enhancement and Consumer Data Protection Act of 2007" amends Section 1030(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code to include protection of personal electronic records and criminal penalties for unauthorized access to protected computers. SEC. 3 amends Section 1030(e)(2)(B) of title 18, US Code to broaden the scope of criminal penalties for computer use. SEC. 4 amends Section 1961(1)(B) to include computer fraud as a RICO predicate. SEC. 5 addresses cyber-extortion. SEC. 5 amends Section 1030(a)(7) of title 18, US Code to include unauthorized access to a protected computer. SEC. 6 adds conspiracy to commit cyber-crimes to Section 1030(b). SEC. 7 requires notice to law enforcement. The amendment to Chapter 47 of title 18, US Code introduces a criminal penalty for failing to notify law enforcement of a security breach involving personal information. Offenders who possess data with means of identification and knowingly fail to report a major security breach to the Secret Service or FBI can face fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. The amendment to Chapter 47 of title 18, US Code defines a 'breach' as a security breach involving 10,000 or more individuals' means of identification, Federal Government databases, or data related to national security or law enforcement. A significant risk of identity theft is determined by a reasonable person after a reasonable opportunity. The amendment to Chapter 47 of title 18, US Code defines a 'breach' as a security breach involving 10,000 or more individuals' means of identification, Federal Government databases, or data related to national security or law enforcement. A significant risk of identity theft is determined by a reasonable person after a reasonable opportunity. If the data involved in a suspected breach is encrypted or rendered unusable, there is a presumption that the breach has not caused a significant risk of identity theft, unless facts demonstrate otherwise. Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Attorney General and Secretary of Homeland Security will establish rules for notifying individuals of data breaches. The rules will not mandate specific products or technologies for data protection. The rules and regulations for notifying individuals of data breaches will require notifying the United States Secret Service or FBI before informing consumers, with a possible delay if it hinders a criminal investigation or national security. The United States Secret Service or FBI must be notified before informing consumers of data breaches, with possible delays if it impacts criminal investigations or national security. The Secret Service will notify the FBI if the breach involves espionage, foreign counterintelligence, or national defense information. The Secret Service or FBI will also inform the Attorney General in each state. Investigation notifies the Attorney General in each State affected by the breach if the Secret Service or FBI declines to pursue a criminal investigation. Immunity from lawsuit is granted to law enforcement entities or individuals who notify law enforcement of a security breach. Failure to notify under section 1039 of title 18, US Code, incurs a civil penalty of up to $50,000 per day, not exceeding $1,000,000. This requirement does not override State laws. The requirement to notify law enforcement under this section supersedes any other notice required by State law. The notice to law enforcement is in addition to any consumer notice required by State or Federal law after a security breach. Federal agencies must notify of a major security breach as if they were a person under section 1039 of title 18, US Code. Federal agencies must notify the United States Secret Service or Federal Bureau of Investigation of a major security breach in the same way as a person under section 1039 of title 18, US Code. The rulemaking authority includes making rules for this notification. SEC. 8. PENALTIES FOR SECTION 1030 VIOLATIONS. SEC. 8. PENALTIES FOR SECTION 1030 VIOLATIONS. Subsection (c) of section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to increase punishment for offenses under subsection (a) or (b) to a fine, imprisonment for up to 30 years, or both. Offenders must forfeit any property used in the violation and any proceeds obtained as a result. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and increase penalties for offenses related to computer crime and misuse of personally identifiable data. Factors to be considered include creating an effective deterrent to such crimes. The United States Sentencing Commission is tasked with reviewing and enhancing penalties for computer crime and misuse of personally identifiable data. Factors to be considered include the level of sophistication, financial motivation, loss incurred, intent to cause harm, privacy violations, impact on government operations, and involvement of government computers in defense or security. The United States Sentencing Commission is reviewing penalties for computer crime and misuse of data, considering factors like sophistication, financial motivation, harm intent, privacy violations, impact on government operations, and involvement of government computers in defense or security. The Commission will also assess aggravating or mitigating circumstances and make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission is reviewing penalties for computer crime and misuse of data, considering factors like sophistication, financial motivation, harm intent, privacy violations, impact on government operations, and involvement of government computers in defense or security. The Commission will also assess aggravating or mitigating circumstances and make necessary changes to sentencing guidelines to ensure they meet the purposes of sentencing as set forth in section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 10 amends Section 1030(a)(5)(B) of title 18, United States Code to include damage affecting ten or more protected computers in a 1-year period. It also amends Section 1030(g) and Section 2332b(g)(5)(B)(i) to reflect these changes. SEC. 11 provides additional funding for resources to investigate and prosecute criminal activity involving computers. Additional funding of $10,000,000 each is authorized for the United States Secret Service, the Department of Justice's Criminal Division, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for fiscal years 2007 through 2011. The funds will remain available until expended and are to be used for investigating and prosecuting criminal activity involving computers. The Secret Service, FBI, and DOJ are authorized to hire and train law enforcement officers to investigate and prosecute crimes involving computers and to procure advanced forensic tools for this purpose.
